texts.shortText: Encrusting species formed of thick dark-green ear-like lobes that are free from the substratum along the growing edges, but attached centrally by patches of rhizoids. Younger lobes rounded, but older ones irregularly cleft into lobes. Utricles with a constriction below tip giving them a ‘nine-pin’ shape.
Lobes up to 5 mm thick and up to 300 mm diameter.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: St Helena Bay to Southern KwaZulu-Natal.

Distinctive species that forms large colonies in lowshore pools and on shallow reefs. Extensively fed on by green sap-sucking sea slugs of the genera Placida and Elysia, which penetrate the large calls and suck up the contents, including the chloroplasts, which continue to photosynthesize within the slugs’ bodies, making them essentially ‘solar-powered’.

Can reproduce asexually by fragmentation allowing it to rapidly colonise new areas. Sexual reproduction in this genus is variable and complex and can involve production of parthenogenetically developing ‘swarmer cells’, or separate males and females producing spores from reproductive structures on the surfaces of the utricles.
Could be confused with Lucas‘ codium C. lucasi, but that species is formed of smaller, sausage-like lobes that form irregular mats that are strongly adherent to the substratum.

Anderson, RJ, Stegenga, H & Bolton, JJ (2016). Seaweeds of the South African South Coast. World Wide Web electronic publication, University of Cape Town, http://southafrseaweeds.uct.ac.za; Accessed on 22 July 2024.

Silva, PC (1959). The genus Codium (Chlorophyta) in South Africa. Journal of South African Botany, 25, 101-165.
